push-ups.name: Push-Ups
cues: Hands shoulder-width apart, fingers pointing forward.
Body in a straight line from head to heels.
Lower your chest to the floor, keeping elbows at a 45-degree angle.
Press through your palms to return to the start.

incline-push-ups.name: Incline Push-Ups
cues: Place hands on a bench or elevated surface.
The higher the surface, the easier the exercise.
Maintain a straight body line.
Focus on full range of motion.

decline-push-ups.name: Decline Push-Ups
cues: Place feet on a bench or elevated surface.
This increases the load on your upper chest and shoulders.
Keep your core tight to prevent your back from sagging.
Control the movement throughout.

bodyweight-squats.name: Bodyweight Squats
cues: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, toes slightly out.
Keep your chest up and core engaged.
Push your hips back and bend your knees as if sitting in a chair.
Go down until thighs are at least parallel to the floor.
Drive through your heels to stand back up.

box-squats.name: Box Squats
cues: Place a box or chair behind you.
Squat down until you gently touch the box.
Pause for a second, then stand back up.
This helps control depth and build confidence.

jump-squats.name: Jump Squats
cues: Perform a regular squat, then explode upward into a jump.
Land softly on the balls of your feet.
Immediately absorb the impact and go into the next rep.
Use your arms for momentum.

plank.name: Plank
cues: Position on forearms, elbows directly under shoulders.
Maintain a straight line from head to heels.
Engage your core and glutes to prevent hip sag.
Breathe steadily throughout the hold.

knee-plank.name: Knee Plank
cues: Perform the plank on your knees instead of your toes.
Keep a straight line from your head to your knees.
Focus on feeling the contraction in your abs.
Gradually increase hold time.

plank-arm-leg-lift.name: Plank with Arm/Leg Lift
cues: From a stable plank, slowly lift one arm or leg off the ground.
Hold for 2-3 seconds without letting your hips rotate.
Alternate limbs.
This challenges your core stability.

forward-lunges.name: Forward Lunges
cues: Step forward with one leg.
Lower your hips until both knees are bent at a 90-degree angle.
Keep your front knee over your ankle, not past your toes.
Push off the front foot to return to the starting position.

static-split-squats.name: Static Split Squats
cues: Start in a staggered stance without the stepping motion.
Lower and raise your body, focusing on balance.
Complete all reps on one side before switching.
Use a wall for support if needed.

walking-lunges.name: Walking Lunges
cues: Instead of pushing back, step forward with the back leg into the next lunge.
This creates a continuous walking motion.
Maintain an upright torso and engaged core.
Cover a set distance or number of steps.

glute-bridges.name: Glute Bridges
cues: Lie on your back with knees bent, feet flat on the floor hip-width apart.
Drive through your heels and lift your hips toward the ceiling.
Squeeze your glutes hard at the top.
Lower your hips back down with control.

partial-glute-bridges.name: Partial Glute Bridges
cues: Lift your hips only halfway up.
Focus on initiating the movement by squeezing your glutes.
Hold the top position for a moment.
Gradually increase the range of motion.

single-leg-glute-bridge.name: Single-Leg Glute Bridge
cues: Extend one leg straight out.
Drive through the heel of the planted foot to lift your hips.
Keep your hips level throughout the movement.
Complete all reps on one side before switching.

burpees.name: Burpees
cues: Start standing, then drop into a squat with hands on the floor.
Kick your feet back to a plank position.
Perform a push-up.
Jump your feet back to the squat position and jump up explosively.

no-push-up-burpee.name: No Push-Up Burpee
cues: Perform the burpee motion without the push-up.
You can also step your feet back and forward instead of jumping.
Focus on a steady pace.
This reduces the intensity and strength requirement.

burpee-tuck-jump.name: Burpee with Tuck Jump
cues: At the top of the burpee, instead of a standard jump, pull your knees to your chest.
This adds an explosive, athletic component.
Land softly and transition smoothly into the next rep.
Increases cardiovascular demand significantly.

mountain-climbers.name: Mountain Climbers
cues: Start in a high plank position.
Keep your back flat and abs engaged.
Drive one knee towards your chest, then quickly switch legs.
Maintain a running or climbing motion.

slow-mountain-climbers.name: Slow Mountain Climbers
cues: Perform the movement slowly and deliberately.
Pause for a second with each knee drive.
Focus on core stability and control.
This builds foundational strength.

cross-body-mountain-climbers.name: Cross-Body Mountain Climbers
cues: Drive your knee towards the opposite elbow.
This twisting motion engages your obliques more.
Keep your hips low and stable.
Adds a rotational challenge to the core.

hollow-body-hold.name: Hollow Body Hold
cues: Lie on your back, press your lower back into the floor.
Lift your legs and shoulders slightly off the ground.
Keep arms and legs extended, creating a 'banana' shape.
Hold the position, keeping your core tight.

tuck-hollow-hold.name: Tuck Hollow Hold
cues: Bend your knees and bring them towards your chest.
This shortens the lever, making it easier to hold.
Keep your lower back pressed into the floor.
Gradually extend your legs as you get stronger.

hollow-body-rocks.name: Hollow Body Rocks
cues: From the hollow hold, gently rock back and forth.
Maintain the hollow shape throughout the rock.
The movement should be small and controlled.
This adds a dynamic challenge to core stability.

superman.name: Superman
cues: Lie face down with arms and legs extended.
Simultaneously lift your arms, chest, and legs off the floor.
Squeeze your glutes and lower back.
Hold for a moment at the top, then lower with control.

alternating-superman.name: Alternating Superman
cues: Lift your right arm and left leg simultaneously.
Lower and then lift your left arm and right leg.
This reduces the load and helps with coordination.
Focus on slow, controlled movements.

superman-flutter-kicks.name: Superman Hold with Flutter Kicks
cues: Hold the top position of the superman.
Perform small, quick flutter kicks with your legs.
Keep your chest and arms lifted.
This increases time under tension and difficulty.

pistol-squat.name: Pistol Squat
cues: Balance on one leg, extending the other leg forward.
Lower yourself into a full squat on the standing leg.
Keep your heel on the ground and chest up.
Drive through your heel to return to the standing position.

box-pistol-squat.name: Box Pistol Squat
cues: Perform the movement while squatting down to a bench or box.
This limits the range of motion and provides a target.
Use a higher box to make it easier, lower for harder.
Focus on control and balance.

elevated-pistol-squat.name: Elevated Pistol Squat
cues: Stand on a box or bench.
This allows your non-working leg to drop lower.
It requires more strength as there's no 'bottoming out'.
Focus on a deep, controlled squat.

pull-ups.name: Pull-ups
cues: Grip the bar with palms facing away, slightly wider than shoulders.
Start from a dead hang with arms fully extended.
Pull your chest towards the bar by driving your elbows down.
Lower yourself with control until arms are straight again.

band-assisted-pull-ups.name: Band-Assisted Pull-ups
cues: Loop a resistance band around the bar and place your feet or knees in it.
The band provides assistance at the bottom of the movement.
Use a thicker band for more help, a thinner one for less.
Focus on the same pulling mechanics.

weighted-pull-ups.name: Weighted Pull-ups
cues: Add weight using a dip belt or by holding a dumbbell between your feet.
This overloads the muscles for strength and size.
Maintain strict form; don't sacrifice quality for weight.
Start with a light weight and increase gradually.

chin-ups.name: Chin-ups
cues: Grip the bar with palms facing you, shoulder-width apart.
Pull up until your chin is over the bar.
Focus on squeezing your biceps at the top.
Lower yourself fully with control.

negative-chin-ups.name: Negative Chin-ups
cues: Jump or use a box to get your chin over the bar.
Lower yourself as slowly as possible (aim for 3-5 seconds).
This builds the eccentric (lowering) strength.
Reset and repeat.

close-grip-chin-ups.name: Close-Grip Chin-ups
cues: Bring your hands closer together on the bar.
This increases the focus and demand on your biceps.
Pull your chest to the bar.
Keep the movement strict and controlled.

hanging-leg-raises.name: Hanging Leg Raises
cues: Hang from the bar with arms extended.
Keep your legs straight and together.
Raise your legs as high as you can without swinging.
Lower your legs slowly and with control.

hanging-knee-raises.name: Hanging Knee Raises
cues: Hang from the bar with arms extended.
Bend your knees and raise them towards your chest.
This shortens the lever, making it easier.
Focus on using your abs, not momentum.

toes-to-bar.name: Toes-to-Bar
cues: Initiate the movement by pulling down on the bar with your lats.
Use your abs to bring your toes up to touch the bar.
Requires a combination of strength and coordination.
Control the descent to avoid excessive swinging.

dumbbell-bicep-curls.name: Dumbbell Bicep Curls
cues: Stand with dumbbells at your sides, palms forward.
Keep elbows pinned to your sides.
Curl weights up toward shoulders without swinging your body.
Squeeze biceps at the top and lower with control.

seated-bicep-curls.name: Seated Bicep Curls
cues: Sit on a bench or chair for stability.
This helps prevent using momentum from your lower body.
Focus on isolating the bicep muscle.
Use a lighter weight to perfect form.

incline-dumbbell-curls.name: Incline Dumbbell Curls
cues: Lie back on an incline bench (30-45 degrees).
This puts your biceps in a stretched position, increasing the difficulty.
Let your arms hang straight down before curling.
Keep your shoulders back and down.

bent-over-dumbbell-rows.name: Bent-Over Dumbbell Rows
cues: Hinge at your hips with a slight bend in your knees, back straight.
Pull dumbbells to your lower ribs, keeping elbows close to your body.
Squeeze your shoulder blades together at the top.
Control the weight on the way down.

chest-supported-row.name: Chest-Supported Row
cues: Lie face down on an incline bench.
This supports your torso and isolates the back muscles.
Row the dumbbells up, squeezing your back.
Prevents cheating and protects the lower back.

renegade-rows.name: Renegade Rows
cues: Start in a plank position holding dumbbells.
Row one dumbbell up while maintaining a stable plank.
Keep your hips level and core extremely tight.
Alternate arms with each rep.

dumbbell-bench-press.name: Dumbbell Bench Press
cues: Lie on a flat bench with a dumbbell in each hand.
Keep your feet flat on the floor and back slightly arched.
Press the weights straight up over your chest.
Lower with control until the dumbbells are near your chest.

dumbbell-floor-press.name: Dumbbell Floor Press
cues: Lie on the floor instead of a bench.
This limits the range of motion, which can be safer for shoulders.
Press up from the floor, stopping when your elbows touch down.
Focus on a powerful press.

incline-dumbbell-press.name: Incline Dumbbell Press
cues: Set the bench to a 30-45 degree incline.
This targets the upper portion of your chest.
Press the dumbbells up and slightly back.
Keep your core engaged to maintain stability on the incline.

dumbbell-overhead-press.name: Dumbbell Overhead Press
cues: Sit or stand with dumbbells at shoulder height, palms forward.
Keep your core tight and back straight.
Press the dumbbells directly overhead until your arms are fully extended.
Lower the weights back to your shoulders with control.

seated-overhead-press.name: Seated Overhead Press
cues: Sitting on a bench with back support provides more stability.
This allows you to focus purely on the pressing motion.
Prevents using leg drive to cheat the weight up.
Ideal for learning the movement pattern.

arnold-press.name: Arnold Press
cues: Start with palms facing you at shoulder height.
As you press up, rotate your palms to face forward at the top.
Reverse the motion on the way down.
This hits all three heads of the deltoid.

bulgarian-split-squats.name: Bulgarian Split Squats
cues: Place the top of your back foot on a bench behind you.
Hold dumbbells in each hand.
Lower your back knee towards the floor, keeping your front knee aligned with your foot.
Drive through your front heel to return to the start.

bodyweight-bulgarian-split-squats.name: Bodyweight Bulgarian Split Squats
cues: Perform the exercise without any dumbbells.
Focus on balance and achieving a full range of motion.
This is a challenging exercise even with just bodyweight.
Master the form before adding weight.

deficit-bulgarian-split-squats.name: Deficit Bulgarian Split Squats
cues: Elevate your front foot on a small platform (like a weight plate).
This increases the range of motion and the stretch on the glutes.
Requires excellent mobility and control.
Use lighter weight when first attempting.

kettlebell-swings.name: Kettlebell Swings
cues: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, kettlebell in front.
Hinge at your hips to grab the kettlebell.
Hike the bell back between your legs, then explosively drive your hips forward.
Swing the kettlebell to chest height, letting your arms guide it.
This is a hip hinge, not a squat.

kettlebell-deadlifts.name: Kettlebell Deadlifts
cues: Practice the hip hinge movement without the explosive swing.
Stand over the kettlebell, hinge at the hips, and lift.
Focus on keeping your back flat and driving with your glutes.
This builds the foundational pattern for the swing.

single-arm-kettlebell-swings.name: Single-Arm Kettlebell Swings
cues: Perform the swing with one arm.
This requires more core strength to prevent your body from rotating.
Keep your non-working arm out for balance.
Switch arms halfway through the set or each set.

kettlebell-goblet-squats.name: Kettlebell Goblet Squats
cues: Hold the kettlebell by the horns at chest level.
Keep your elbows tucked in.
Squat down, keeping your chest up and back straight.
The weight in front helps you maintain an upright posture.
Drive through your heels to stand up.

double-kettlebell-front-squat.name: Double Kettlebell Front Squat
cues: Clean two kettlebells into the rack position.
This significantly increases the load and core demand.
Requires strong wrists and core to maintain the rack position.
Keep your elbows high and torso upright.

turkish-get-up.name: Turkish Get-Up
cues: A complex, multi-step movement from lying to standing.
Keep your eyes on the kettlebell at all times.
Move slowly and deliberately through each step.
Focus on stability and control, not speed.

half-turkish-get-up.name: Half Turkish Get-Up
cues: Perform only the first few steps, up to the seated position.
This builds core and shoulder stability for the full movement.
Practice without weight first to learn the sequence.
Master this before attempting the full get-up.

bottoms-up-turkish-get-up.name: Bottoms-Up Turkish Get-Up
cues: Hold the kettlebell upside down (bottoms-up).
This requires immense grip strength and shoulder stability.
Use a very light weight.
Any deviation in form will cause you to lose control of the bell.

resistance-band-rows.name: Resistance Band Rows
cues: Anchor the band securely in front of you at chest height.
Pull the band toward your ribs, keeping elbows close to your body.
Squeeze your shoulder blades together at the peak of the contraction.
Control the band as you return to the starting position.

lighter-resistance-band-rows.name: Lighter Resistance Band Rows
cues: Use a band with less tension.
This allows you to focus on form and the mind-muscle connection.
Complete the full range of motion with control.
Perfect the movement before increasing resistance.

single-arm-band-rows.name: Single-Arm Band Rows
cues: Perform the row with one arm at a time.
This challenges your core to resist rotation.
You can often achieve a greater range of motion.
Focus on squeezing the lat of the working side.

band-pull-aparts.name: Band Pull-Aparts
cues: Hold a light band with an overhand grip, hands shoulder-width apart.
Raise your arms straight out in front of you.
Keeping your arms straight, pull the band apart by squeezing your shoulder blades.
Return to the start with control. Don't let the band snap back.

wider-grip-band-pull-aparts.name: Wider Grip Band Pull-Aparts
cues: Place your hands further apart on the band.
This reduces the effective resistance.
Focus on initiating the movement from your back, not your arms.
Excellent for shoulder health and posture.

pause-band-pull-aparts.name: Pause Band Pull-Aparts
cues: Hold the fully contracted position for 2-3 seconds.
This increases time under tension for the target muscles.
Fight the urge to rush the reps.
Focus on a powerful squeeze in your upper back.

bench-dips.name: Bench Dips
cues: Sit on the edge of a bench, hands beside your hips.
Slide your hips forward off the bench, supporting your weight with your arms.
Lower your body by bending your elbows until they are at a 90-degree angle.
Press through your palms to return to the start.

bent-knee-bench-dips.name: Bent-Knee Bench Dips
cues: Keep your knees bent and feet flat on the floor.
This reduces the amount of bodyweight you have to lift.
Focus on feeling the contraction in your triceps.
Keep your back close to the bench.

feet-elevated-bench-dips.name: Feet-Elevated Bench Dips
cues: Place your feet on another bench or elevated surface in front of you.
This increases the load on your triceps and shoulders.
You can add a weight plate to your lap for even more resistance.
Maintain control throughout the movement.

box-jumps.name: Box Jumps
cues: Stand in front of the bench or box.
Dip into a quarter squat and explode up, swinging your arms for momentum.
Land softly on the center of the box with your knees bent.
Step down, do not jump down.

step-ups.name: Step-Ups
cues: Place one foot fully on the bench.
Drive through the heel of the front foot to lift your body up.
Bring the other foot to meet it on the bench.
Step back down with the same trailing foot.

tuck-jump-box.name: Tuck Jump onto Box
cues: As you jump, pull your knees high towards your chest.
This requires more power and coordination.
Use a slightly lower box than your max height for safety.
Land in a deep squat position.

lower-step-ups.name: Lower Step-Ups
cues: Use a lower surface if a standard bench is too high.
This reduces the range of motion and strength required.
Focus on control and balance.
Gradually increase the height as you get stronger.

weighted-step-ups.name: Weighted Step-Ups
cues: Hold dumbbells in each hand to increase the load.
You can also add a high knee drive at the top for an extra challenge.
Keep your torso upright and core engaged.
This builds serious single-leg strength.

barbell-back-squat.name: Barbell Back Squat
cues: Position the bar on your upper back (traps), not your neck.
Keep your chest up and back straight.
Squat down by pushing your hips back and bending your knees.
Drive through your heels to stand back up.

pause-squat.name: Pause Squat
cues: Pause at the bottom of the squat for 2-3 seconds.
Maintain tension and a tight core throughout the pause.
Explode up from the bottom position.
Builds strength out of the most difficult part of the lift.

barbell-bench-press.name: Barbell Bench Press
cues: Lie with your eyes under the bar, feet firmly on the floor.
Grip slightly wider than your shoulders.
Keep your shoulder blades retracted and down on the bench.
Lower the bar to your mid-chest, then press up powerfully.

close-grip-bench-press.name: Close-Grip Bench Press
cues: Take a shoulder-width grip on the bar.
Keep your elbows tucked in close to your body as you lower the bar.
This places more emphasis on the triceps.
Lower the bar to your lower chest.

barbell-deadlift.name: Barbell Deadlift
cues: Start with the bar over your midfoot, feet hip-width apart.
Keep your back straight, chest up, and hips down.
Drive the floor away with your legs to lift the bar.
Squeeze your glutes to lock out at the top. Don't hyperextend.

romanian-deadlift.name: Romanian Deadlift (RDL)
cues: Start from the top position.
Hinge at your hips, keeping your legs almost straight (slight knee bend).
Lower the bar to just below your knees, feeling a deep stretch in your hamstrings.
This variation emphasizes the hamstrings and glutes.

barbell-overhead-press.name: Barbell Overhead Press
cues: Start with the bar in the front rack position on your shoulders.
Grip just outside your shoulders.
Keep your core and glutes tight to create a stable base.
Press the bar straight overhead, moving your head back slightly to clear the path.

push-press.name: Push Press
cues: Initiate the movement with a slight dip and drive from your legs.
This momentum helps you press heavier weight.
It turns the lift into a more full-body, explosive movement.
Catch the bar back on your shoulders on the way down.

barbell-bent-over-row.name: Barbell Bent-Over Row
cues: Hinge at the hips until your torso is nearly parallel to the floor.
Grip the bar with an overhand grip, slightly wider than your shoulders.
Pull the bar to your lower chest / upper abdomen.
Squeeze your back muscles at the top and lower with control.

pendlay-row.name: Pendlay Row
cues: Start with the barbell on the floor for every rep.
Explosively pull the bar from a dead stop to your chest.
Return the bar to the floor under control.
This builds explosive power in the back.

landmine-press.name: Landmine Press
cues: Stand facing the landmine, holding the end of the barbell with both hands.
Press the bar up and forward in an arc.
Keep your core tight to prevent your back from arching.
Control the weight on the way down.

half-kneeling-landmine-press.name: Half-Kneeling Landmine Press
cues: Kneel on one knee for a more stable base.
This reduces the demand on your core and improves stability.
Allows you to focus on the pressing motion with one arm.
Press with the arm on the same side as the down knee.

landmine-push-press.name: Landmine Push Press
cues: Add a dip and drive with your legs to initiate the press.
Use momentum from your lower body to help press the weight.
This allows you to lift heavier and is more athletic.
A more explosive, full-body movement.

landmine-row.name: Landmine Row
cues: Stand straddling the barbell and hinge at your hips.
Keep your back straight and nearly parallel to the floor.
Grip the bar with both hands (using a V-handle is common).
Pull the end of the bar to your chest, squeezing your back.

meadows-row.name: Meadows Row
cues: Stand perpendicular to the bar, using one arm.
This allows for a greater range of motion and a different angle of pull.
Use your non-working arm to brace against your knee.
Targets the upper back and lats effectively.

landmine-rotational-twist.name: Landmine Rotational Twist
cues: Stand facing the landmine, holding the end of the bar with both hands, arms extended.
Keeping your arms straight, rotate your torso to move the bar in an arc from one hip to the other.
Pivot on your feet as you twist.
Control the movement with your core.

bodyweight-torso-twists.name: Bodyweight Torso Twists
cues: Practice the rotational movement without weight.
Focus on feeling your obliques contract.
Keep your hips stable and rotate from your upper spine.
This builds the mind-muscle connection.

explosive-landmine-twists.name: Explosive Landmine Twists
cues: Increase the speed of the rotation while maintaining control.
This makes the exercise more powerful and athletic.
Focus on snapping the bar from side to side.
Ensure your core stays braced throughout.

parallette-dips.name: Parallette Dips
cues: Start in a support hold on the parallettes, arms straight.
Keep your chest up and shoulders down.
Lower your body by bending your elbows, keeping them tucked in.
Go as deep as you comfortably can, then press back up.

foot-assisted-dips.name: Foot-Assisted Dips
cues: Keep your feet on the floor in front of you.
Use your legs to assist with the movement.
This reduces the amount of bodyweight you need to lift.
Focus on the upper body doing most of the work.

weighted-dips.name: Weighted Dips
cues: Use a dip belt to add weight or hold a dumbbell between your feet.
This overloads the muscles for greater strength gains.
Ensure you can do at least 10-12 bodyweight dips with good form first.
Maintain control and full range of motion.

parallette-l-sit.name: Parallette L-Sit
cues: Start in a support hold, arms locked out.
Lift your legs straight out in front of you, parallel to the floor.
Keep your toes pointed and legs together.
Depress your shoulders (push them down) and hold.

tuck-l-sit.name: Tuck L-Sit
cues: Instead of keeping legs straight, bend your knees and tuck them in.
This is a much easier position to hold.
Focus on keeping your hips high.
Gradually extend your legs as you get stronger.

v-sit.name: V-Sit
cues: From the L-Sit, continue to raise your legs higher.
Aim to get your torso and legs into a 'V' shape.
This requires significantly more core compression and strength.
Keep your arms locked and shoulders depressed.

parallette-push-ups.name: Parallette Push-Ups
cues: Grip the parallettes with a neutral grip, hands under your shoulders.
The parallettes allow for a deeper range of motion.
Lower your chest below the level of your hands.
Press back up to the starting position.

incline-parallette-push-ups.name: Incline Parallette Push-Ups
cues: Place the parallettes on an elevated surface like a bench.
This reduces the amount of bodyweight you are pushing.
Focus on getting a full range of motion.
A great way to build up to flat push-ups.

feet-elevated-parallette-push-ups.name: Feet-Elevated Parallette Push-Ups
cues: Place your feet on a bench or box.
This increases the load on your upper chest and shoulders.
The deficit from the parallettes makes this very challenging.
Keep your core tight to maintain a straight body line.

parallette-tuck-planche.name: Parallette Tuck Planche
cues: From a support hold, lean your shoulders forward past your hands.
Tuck your knees to your chest and lift your feet off the ground.
Keep your arms locked straight and protract your shoulder blades.
Aim to have your back parallel to the floor.

planche-leans.name: Planche Leans
cues: Start in a push-up position on the parallettes.
Lean your shoulders as far forward as you can, keeping arms straight.
Hold the lean for time to build shoulder strength.
This is the foundational strength builder for the planche.

advanced-tuck-planche.name: Advanced Tuck Planche
cues: From the tuck planche, open your hips to flatten your back.
Your back should be perfectly parallel to the ground.
This is a significant step up in difficulty.
Requires more forward lean and shoulder strength.

knee-push-ups.name: Knee Push-Ups
cues: Perform push-ups from your knees instead of your toes.
Keep a straight line from your head to your knees.
Lower your chest toward the floor.
This reduces the amount of bodyweight you're pushing.

diamond-push-ups.name: Diamond Push-Ups
cues: Place your hands close together, forming a diamond shape with thumbs and index fingers.
Keep your elbows close to your body as you lower down.
This significantly increases tricep activation.
Maintain a straight body line throughout.
